title: Ancient Hand Painting Shows Early Human Creativity
summary: Scientists found a very old painting of a hand in a cave on an island called Sulawesi in Indonesia. This painting is special because it is the oldest known cave art in the world, made at least 67,800 years ago. It shows a red outline of a hand that looks like a claw, which means people long ago were starting to think in creative ways. This discovery helps us learn that humans were making art and telling stories much earlier than we thought, not just in Europe but in other places too. It shows that creativity is a natural part of being human, going back to our origins in Africa. The painting was made by someone pressing their hand against a cave wall and blowing red pigment around it to leave a hand shape. This find changes what we know about when humans began to use symbols and imagination.

background_read: This article is about an ancient cave painting discovered in Indonesia. Cave paintings are pictures made by early humans on walls, often showing hands, animals, or scenes. They help scientists understand how people long ago thought and expressed themselves. The find in Sulawesi is special because it is the oldest known, dating back over 67,000 years, which challenges old ideas that art began in Europe. It shows that humans have been creative and using symbols for a very long time, which is linked to how we develop language and stories. Learning about this helps us see that creativity is a key part of human history across the world.
